title: What proportion of seats will the MPLA win in Angola's upcoming parliamentary elections?
possible_answers: A plurality, but not a majority
preds:
Angola's ruling MPLA party has won the country's parliamentary elections, but lost ground to the opposition, the electoral commission said citing provisional results.  The MPLA took 61.1 percent of the votes counted compared with the opposition UNITA party's 26.7 percent, results showed on Friday.
http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/170825124719728.html

MPLA reportedly wins 150 of the 220 seats, giving it a two thirds majority.
http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/170825124719728.html

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-angola-election-idUSKCN1B40XM With 63.74% of the votes cast having been counted, MPLA has a commanding lead of 64.57%, compared to  the opposition UNITA party's 24.4 percent. . . .MPLA earlier said it was on track to win a two-thirds parliamentary majority, based on its own numbers.

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/angola-elect-president-dos-santos-retires-170822072622989.html
No particular reason to suppose the MPLA won't hang on a while longer.
Since the power structure remains the same; the outcome should be the same.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-17/angola-ruling-party-candidate-a-chauffeur-opposition-says " . . . the ruling party is expected to win with 61 percent of votes, according to a poll posted on the website of the Institute Jean Piaget of Benguela in Portugal. " . . . opposition parties are struggling to make their voices heard in Angola’s state-owned media, which gives more airtime to the MPLA.  “Whatever decision needs to be taken on any issue, they’ll have an absolute majority,” Samakuva [head of the opposition  National Union for the Total Liberation of Angola, or Unita] said.
~~~~~~
https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21726746-ruling-party-will-probably-win-coming-election-corruption "There are signs, though, that the MPLA’s stranglehold on Angolan politics is loosening. Its leader, José Eduardo dos Santos, is stepping down as president after 38 years in power. His handpicked successor, João Lourenço, does not have the same standing within the party—nor does he inspire the same fear in its opponents. Moreover, 66% of the country’s 28m people are under 25. Many will be voting for the first time. With little memory of the war, they tend to be more cynical about the MPLA.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-angola-politics-opposition-idUSKCN1AW14E " . . . a lack of credible polling in the country makes the result unpredictable."
~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Oil wealth has fueled a prolonged construction boom in the country, but the gleaming buildings and road construction statistics obscure problems.  Much of the construction was very shoddy work and is already crumbling; this is evidence of massive corruption in the government & construction sectors.  Imported/foreign labor was employed in these construction projects, leaving the Angolan workforce unemployed and inexperienced.  In the last year, there has been a significant depression due to low oil prices.  All of this means that the ordinary Angolan may have grown displeased with MPLA.   However, MPLA holds 175 out of 220 seats:  to lose its majority it would have to have a disastrous election result and lose more than 1/3rd of them.  I have read nothing that leads me to think that MPLA would suffer such  a disastrous loss. I suspect that the unpredictability that Reuters referred to is to how many seats each party will win, not which party will win the majority. I am particularly appreciative of the thorough and extensive analysis of this question done by @ErikFritzsche http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/529428

In German Election Campaign, Third Place Is the Real Winner Troianovski (2017) Aug 13, states that: Germany’s general election campaign kicked off in earnest over the weekend and it promises to be a nail-biter—for third place. Chancellor Angela Merkel looks like a sure bet to win a fourth term as the head of Europe’s biggest economic power when the country votes in late September. Her center-right alliance has a 15-point polling lead over its closest challenger, the center-left Social Democratic Party, or SPD, of candidate Martin Schulz. Ms. Merkel’s campaign slogan—“For a Germany in which we live well and happily”—channels a public mood wary of change. In a 40-minute speech to supporters in the city of Dortmund on Saturday that opened six weeks of campaigning, she didn’t even mention her opponent by name. But behind the confident Ms. Merkel and the struggling Mr. Schulz are four smaller parties in a mad dash for the bronze—a race likely to determine the makeup of the next government and Germany’s political direction for the next four years. Ms. Merkel is almost certain to need a coalition partner to govern. Only once since World War II has a single party won an outright majority. Ms. Merkel’s current government is a “grand coalition” bringing together Germany’s two main political blocs—her conservatives and Mr. Schulz’s Social Democrats. His party disdains governing in Ms. Merkel’s shadow, and conservatives also say that such a broad coalition should be the exception rather than the rule in German democracy (para. 1-5). Troianovski, A. (2017). In German Election Campaign, Third Place Is the Real Winner. The Wall Street Journal. World. Europe. Retrieved from
https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-german-election-campaign-third-place-is-the-real-winner-1502622031

https://mg.co.za/article/2017-08-04-00-editorial-in-despair-over-elections "In Angola, President José Eduardo dos Santos is carefully stage-managing his departure from the presidential palace after 38 years in power. Although a new president will be installed after this vote, the governing party is likely to retain an overwhelming majority in Parliament, helped by a concerted campaign to silence opposition voices and independent media.
Well this might come back to bite me but I'm going with the groupthink and switching from 98 to 100.
This party won 99.6% of the votes. The likely delta between this election and last election will be less than 10%. (please note this is an intuitive response and should not be heeded)
Strengthening its hold on the country's governance: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-21/angola-strips-future-president-of-power-to-fire-security-heads.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

The opposition is claiming the MPLA will rig the elections similar to how the allege the 2008 and 2012 elections were rigged (http://cajnewsafrica.com/2017/07/10/doubts-angola-elections-will-be-transparent/).  Separately, here's a good report (https://www.eisa.org.za/pdf/ang2012report.pdf) on the outcome of the 2012 election, how it compared to 2008, the issues with transparency and fairness, and some indicators that may work against the MPLA in the current election (most notably the decrease in share of eligible voters and decrease in turnout of voters supporting the MPLA). However, given the overall strength of the MPLA and the preferential treatment by the media, it's unlikely the MPLA will cede much during this election.
The MPLA has held power for decades and this appears to be a well thought out transition.

The longtime ruling party in Angola is the MPLA.  The democratic socialist party holds 175 of the 220 seats in the National Assembly. The leader of the party, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, has been the President of Angola for 37 years and he is peacefully stepping down this year.  The lowest number of seats the MPLA has held in the past 25 years is 129 and it appears the party is in relatively good shape with the public.  Also, the MPLA is already negotiating a place in government for dos Santos after he retires.

Adjusted to allow for some possibility the MPLA loses by a larger margin than expected. MPLA votes in 2008 were 80%, while decreasing to 72% in 2012. Assuming the MPLA continues losing support at 2%/year, they would still garner 62% of the vote and would still maintain a majority  (unless my math using the D'Hondt method is incorrect, which is a possibility) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_Angola).  Additionally, supporting the premise that the MPLA will win a majority is the reality that the MPLA has gone to great efforts to secure its victory in the elections (http://allafrica.com/stories/201706050563.html).  A lot can happen in the 1.5 remaining months, but the MPLA seems to have a pretty solid hold on the electorate for this next election cycle.

May MPLA implode when dos Santos steps down?
This seems unlikely since Lourenco is already vice president, and he seems fairly strong. Overall, it seems as if dos Santos has carefully planned his retirement and the takeover of his top position. Free and fair elections in Angola?
For assessing the overall quality of democracy in a country, I often rely on the 'Bertelsmann Transformation Index', particularly the Country Reports. They are a great source. The composers are political scientists and country experts. See here for BTI: https://www.bti-project.org/en/home/; the Country Report can be found here: https://www.bti-project.org/fileadmin/files/BTI/Downloads/Reports/2016/pdf/BTI_2016_Angola.pdf. With regard to the indicator "free and fair elections" Angola only scored 3 out of 10. So, it is quite clear that the ruling party normally does interfere in the elections process to its favor. One should also take into account the media and the indicator "freedom of expression": 4 out of 10. Therefore, elections seem to be based on ethnic, not on national matters. That is no good precondition for building a majority against MPLA. See also the indicator "association / assembly rights": 3 out of 10… Angola lacks fundamental preconditions for a fair electoral competition. Angola is on position 102 of 129 at the 'Status Index' which measures the quality of liberal democracy. Is there potential for revolution?
There is. The question is how much. Usually the upheaval for revolutions does not (!) begin at the elections. Usually upheaval begins after elections when citizens realize that there must have been fraud. I think the regime around the MPLA seems quite strong, so it is fairly likely that they will try to influence the political and electoral process in order to get a majority for MPLA. Does an opposition exist?
Yes. 
* Most importantly UNITA. Leader: Isaías Samakuva. They are quite institutionalized since they emerged in the 60s, fought in the independence war and a civil war against (!) the regime in 1975-2002 - which was a Cold War proxy war with UNITA as the US ally.
However, they have no strong democratic identity (the party was Maoist, later Socialist but non-communist…). The power base is ethnic: it is the Ovimbundu ethnic group from the south of the country (6 million out of 25 million living in Angola). Given this history and identity it seems unlikely that they can address a majority.
* There are some other minor parties with ethnic power bases.
* May be the most interesting party is National Liberation Front of Angola. But it is very small, right now. And it seems fairly unlikely to say that they will dispute the MPLA majority in parliament. Finally: There is not much time for an evolution of an MPLA alternative. - And as mentioned: structural preconditions for a fair political competition are lacking. All in all, I start with 95 percent majority for MPLA and 5 percent for plurality. Not a plurality: I consider this option to be less likely than 1 percent. Revolutions do not end start at the ballot, they may start with fraud, however. But that is beyond the scope of the question.

Elections have upcome and upgone in Angola and the MPLA will almost surely keep winning for a while yet.  At least a couple more will upcome before they are seriously threatened.  (Like most other scheduled events, elections are never impending or imminent or just coming; they are always and only upcoming.  This is a basic rule, but no one seems to know why.)
100% is too strong, but yes a majority is the most probable outcome by far unless Angola's electoral system is overthrown in a bloody revolution.
There are advantages to being the only ruling party the country has ever known. See Mozambique or Mexico for decades or, perhaps a better example, Zimbabwe.

Angola's Presidential Council Proposes August 23 for National Vote Stoddard (2017) April 24, states that: Angola's Council of the Republic, a presidential group that consults on national decisions, has proposed Aug. 23 for a national election, state radio reported on Monday, a decision which hangs on President Jose Eduardo dos Santos' approval. Dos Santos, 74, will step down as president after 38 years at the helm but will retain control of the powerful ruling MPLA party. He is Africa's second longest-ruling leader and said in February he will not run in this year's presidential election. The MPLA chose Defence Minister Joao Lourenco, 63, as its presidential candidate last December. Dos Santos, a communist-trained oil engineer and a veteran of the guerrilla war against Portuguese rule, will remain president of the MPLA, retaining sweeping powers over what has become Africa's No. 2 crude producer and third largest economy (para. 1-4). Stoddard, E. (2017). Angola's Presidential Council Proposes August 23 for National Vote. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-angola-politics-idUSKBN17Q1A6

dos Santos may be stepping down but he will want to keep the MPLA in control.  There may be a bit more opposition but it will be in a minority role.  The power structure will keep things under control.
The MPLA has held a majority in parliament since independence, why should the future be different?
Never say never, but lots of things have to go spectacularly wrong for a well recognized strongman's  party in a developing nation to lose a majority.

MPLA has held a majority in their parliament since 1980.  Considered the liberation party of Angola, and the primary anti-colonial Marxist revolutionary movement, it has and continues to maintain its hold on power in Angola despite various interludes of civil war with their rivals UNITA.

Angola’s electoral system uses two methods; 127 are elected by closed list proportional representation in a single nationwide constituency, with seats allocated using the d'Hondt method; 90 are elected in 18 five-seat constituencies, also using closed list proportional represenation; the remaining three are elected by Angolans living abroad[1] means that the leader of the party with the most parliamentary seats automatically becomes the head of state. The MPLA holds 175 of the National Assembly’s 220 seats[2]. Lourenco will be confirmed as president in the 2017 vote. There is no viable opposition[3]. References
[1]https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angolan_legislative_election,_2017
[2]https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Assembly_(Angola)
[3]http://country.eiu.com/article.aspx?articleid=1475201331&Country=Angola&topic=Politics
Force of habit is very strong in elections everywhere or the ANC would have vanished from the earth years ago.
